intro: Abies magnifica subsp. shastensis, commonly known as the Shasta fir, is a coniferous evergreen tree native to the western United States. It is characterized by its dense, pyramidal shape and dark green, needle-like leaves that are arranged in spirals along the branches. The cones are typically cylindrical and hang downward, containing winged seeds that are dispersed by wind. This subspecies is adapted to high-altitude environments, often growing in subalpine or alpine regions. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and ecologically important component of mountainous forests.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abies magnifica subsp. shastensis is primarily native to the coastal mountain ranges of northern California and southern Oregon. It is commonly found in the Klamath Mountains and the northern portions of the Sierra Nevada. This subspecies thrives in moist, cool climates with high elevations, typically between 1,500 and 2,500 meters. It is often associated with mixed coniferous forests and grows in areas with well-drained, acidic soils. Its distribution is limited to specific regions where the climate and habitat conditions are suitable for its growth.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abies magnifica subsp. shastensis was mainly introduced to areas with high elevation and cool, moist climates, typically found in mountainous regions of the western United States.
